The historical maps of the digital Bayern-Atlas , an offer of the Bavarian Geoportal to the state government , are far from current - but this is precisely why they are very revealing .
Especially if you compare them with current online maps .
Then it becomes clear how cities and municipalities in the area of distribution of Merkur in Munich have changed since the 19th century .
The digital Bayern-Atlas is a patchwork that cannot be recognized as such .
For cities and municipalities , more detailed maps , so-called primitive maps , have been incorporated into the large overview map .
According to data from the Bavarian survey management , these were established between 1810 and 1864 and originated from Bavaria ’ s first survey .
Your client : Napoleon .
The French army leader occupied Bavaria from the spring of 1800 during the Second Coalition War with Austria .
Napoleon wanted an overview of the occupied land and commissioned a topographical reception of Bavaria , of course for military purposes .
Although the French troops eventually departed with the peace of Lunéville on February 9 , 1801 , it was the current neighbors who created the idea of a comprehensive Bavarian map .
Elector Max IV Joseph pushed the project forward , founded the " Topographische Bureau " - and thus the Bavarian survey management .
The Munich Urpositionsblatt ( Urpositionsblatt ) dates from 1856 and can be found on the website of the Bavarian Landesbibliothek .
The comparison between the former and the present is the most impressive of the provincial capital .
The city has expanded in all directions and has grown together .
An example of this is Untersendling , which still appears relatively isolated in the map of 1856 .
Sendling was incorporated as a Munich-based district 21 years after the map was drawn up in 1877 .
Today Untersendling is in the middle of the city .

The houses of Untersendlings are concentrated around 1856 along the present-day Plinganserstraße , which was only named after Georg Sebastian Plinganser in 1878 , a leader of the uprising of Bavarian farmers against Austria in 1705 .

Where the Westpark is today , you can see nothing but fields - at first glance : when zooming in , a smaller map with dozens of lines and numbers appears : handwritten numbered corridors from the so-called " original photo " from which the property tax was derived .
Today , small plots no longer cover farmers , but small gardeners of the land in the sun .
A large green area is visible north of Untersendling .
The Theresienwiese , the venue of the Oktoberfest since 1810 , was actually a meadow in the 19th century - not a concrete desert .
On the other side of the Isar , the historical map gives an insight into the history of psychiatric medicine .

In the Urpositionsblatt , in the area of today 's Au-Haidhausen district , you can read not only the street name " am Gasteig " or the hill " Auf der Lüften " , but also in large letters " Irren Anstalt " .
Yes , people with delusions were once locked up here on Auerfeldstraße .
The Munich-Kreis-Irrenanstalt " Auf der Auer Lüften " was founded there in 1858 / 59 .
From 1872 onwards , Dr. Bernhard von Gudden led the institution - the psychiatrist who was brought in connection with the death of King Ludwig II .

The National Association for the Promotion of Colors has issued a warning to coloured people travelling to Missouri on the basis of discriminatory policies and racist attacks by the state .

The NAACP Travel Advisory for the State of Missouri , which is due to enter into force by August 28 , 2017 , calls on African-American travelers , visitors and Missourians to pay particular attention and exercise extreme caution when travelling through the state , because a number of dubious race-based incidents have recently been reported throughout the state ,  stated in the Group 's opinion .

A recent Missouri law , which makes it harder for people to take action against discrimination , and the state ’ s law enforcement agencies that disproportionately target minorities , prompted the group to issue travel warnings , said the NAACP .

They have violations of civil rights that happen to people .	-2.5957
They are stopped because of their skin colour , they are beaten up or killed ,  said the president of Missouri NAACP , Rod Chapel , the Kansas City Star .

The group cited incidents such as racist crimes against black students at the University of Missouri and the death of Tory Sanders , 28 , a black man from Tennessee .

The recommendation is that people are aware and inform their families , friends and employees about what could happen in Missouri ,  Chapel said .
'People must be prepared whether they bring bailouts or let relatives know that they are travelling through the state . '

In 2015 , Missouri recorded 100 hate crimes , according to the latest figures from the FBI ’ s hate crime report , ranking the state as the country ’ s 16th country in terms of the number of such violations .
Travel warnings are also a response to a new Missouri law that would make it more difficult to sue a company for housing or employment discrimination .

Trump ’ s White House is now adopting the Statue of Liberty
The safest sign of regime change is when they start attacking the statues .
Americans value them as much as anyone else – hence the carefully staged fall of Saddam Hussein in Firdos Square in Baghdad in 2003 .

Stephen Miller , one of the Trump regime ’ s key ideologues , surely knew what he was doing when he took a symbolic axe into the statue of liberty in a heated dispute with CNN ’ s Jim Acosta about the president ’ s proposals to drastically limit legal immigration .
To be fair , Miller did not attack the statue itself .
A horde of boat owners and liberty-imitators would have lynched him if he had done so .
But he attacked its meaning , and in particular the importance attributed to it when the famous poem of Emma Lazarus was added to its base in 1903 , 17 years after the monument was completed .
When Miller called Acosta , " I don 't want to go into a complete thing about history , but the Statue of Liberty is ... a symbol of American freedom that enlightens the world .
The poem to which you refer , which was added later and is not part of the original Statue of Liberty . '
Miller is factually correct , but as he himself said , it is not really about history .

It is about contemporary resonance with the stirring words of Lazarus , the only one in which a state invites not only some old immigrants , but the poorest of the poor : ' Your pains , your poor , your afflicted masses who yearn to breathe freely / the miserable waste of your rich coasts ' .
There was never a time when the ' miserable waste ' was better seen on our screens .
Miller did not engage in literary criticism – he made it clear that these people are not welcome in Trump ’ s US .
This conflict , because of the importance of a statue , is part of a broader political and cultural debate : indeed , it is a conflict over America ’ s importance .
Lazarus - and her friends who fought to place their words on the ground after their death - knew very well that they were doing a highly political act .
The sculpture was intended to show the connections between French and American republicanism by depicting the female embodiment of freedom in a worn classical pictorial representation .
Lazarus changed this meaning : in her poem , the female figure is no longer abstract - she has received a voice .
And she gives herself a very different name : mother of exiles .
The poem ’ s connection with the picture is a brilliant feminist coup and a devastating attack on American nativism .
And just as Lazarus changed the meaning of the statue , people on the right wanted to change it for a long time .

The great cry of Rush Limbaugh , a kind of John of the Baptist for the coming of Trump , argued in 2010 that the Statue of Liberty was not inviting anyone , but rather an early neo-conservatives who bring the American flame into the surrounding world : " Lady Liberty is moving forward .
It is to carry the torch of freedom from the United States to the rest of the world .
The torch should not illuminate the way to the United States . '
Quite unusual , Limbaugh found something here .
The importance of the statue is entirely a question of the position of perception .
The great imaginative act of Lazarus was to see them as seen by the exhausted , miserable but hopeful people after long and often terrible voyages on the decks of ships .
In the truest sense , it is about seeing the world from the perspective of people seeking refuge and an opportunity to improve their lives .
Their statue speaks to them the words of hope and welcome that they must hear .
And , of course , that is not the perspective that Miller and Trump would ever want to recognize .
Their torch should not illuminate the way , but should ignite hatred , which is their only source of power .

Poverty and Death in Indonesian Gold
When Bardina Degei cooks dinner , she does not use a stove .
It seldom uses a pot .

In her wooden house in Enarotali , the capital of the Paniai regency in the troubled Indonesian province of Papua , the housewife usually puts a sweet potato - locally called " nota " - directly into the fireplace .
After half an hour , the carved bone is removed and swallowed with diligent , unwashed hands .
Degei sits on the mud floor - she has no furniture - where she also performs her daily work , for example washing clothes with cloudy water from the nearby swamp .
A bucket in a rootless room serves as a latrine .
As the youngest of her husband ’ s four wives , she was not assigned any fields .
Polygamy is common here .
Of course , late work can be dangerous : most villagers are unemployed and many drink hard , and there are soldiers here .
Nobody dares to walk around after 5 p.m. in the village ,  she says .

It is a rare glimpse of daily life in the highlands of Papua , a former Dutch colony , which was admitted in 1969 after a controversial referendum in Indonesia , when only 1,026 elders were to vote in public hands before the occupying forces .
An existing movement that stirred up independence against Dutch rule quickly turned against the Jakarta government , which controls the region , excluding foreign journalists or legal observers .
In 2003 , the province was officially divided into Papua and West Papua , with the independent part of Papua New Guinea covering the eastern part of the island .
Enarotali is as remote as it is deserted .
There is no public transport .
The city , with some 19,000 inhabitants , consists of wooden houses surrounded by bamboo fences and corrugated sheet roofs , converted by rust into various yellow brown tones .
Few Indonesians have travelled here , let alone journalists and virtually no foreigners .
Before Christian missionaries arrived , Mee Pago Papuans worshipped a god called Uga Tamee .
There have also been other changes .
We were not used to wearing these clothes ,  says Degei , pointing to her lively , hand-woven turban , her dark shirt and her bright skirt .
'We used to have only leaves on our bodies . '
Papua is Indonesia ’ s poorest province , where 28 % of people live below the poverty line and have some of the worst child mortality and literacy rates in Asia .
But it is also Indonesia ’ s gold country .

The world ’ s largest and most profitable gold mine , Grasberg , owned by Phoenix ’ s McMoran Freeport , is only 60 miles from Paniai , a highland province in the size of New Jersey with 153,000 inhabitants .
In 2015 alone , Freeport lost $ 3.1 billion in gold and copper .
Moreover , Papua has an estimated $ 78 billion worth of wood resources .
But these riches are a source of misery for the Papua , which ensure that Indonesia ’ s powerful military maintains a suffocating presence .
A 2005 study in the New York Times reported that Freeport paid local military and units nearly $ 20 million between 1998 and 2004 , including up to $ 150,000 to a single officer .
Papuan demands for greater autonomy threaten these golden gooses and are treated mercilessly .
According to activists , more than 500,000 Papua have been killed and thousands have been raped , tortured and imprisoned by the Indonesian military since 1969 .
Mass killings in Papua ’ s tribal hemisphere in the 1970 ’ s became genocide , according to the Asian Human Rights Commission .
In the region alone , the Indonesian police arrested more than 3,900 peaceful demonstrators last year .

We Will All Lose  is a 2016 report by the Archdiocese of Brisbane , which contains reports of atrocities committed last year , such as illegal executions and torture - rape and electric strikes are particularly popular after another report - and the brutal suppression of peaceful demonstrations .
It is difficult to count the number of victims because incidents happen every week ,  says Andreas Harsono , Indonesian researcher for Human Rights Watch .
The screws have intensified as Papua 's resources bring an influx of settlers from other parts of Indonesia .

The population of 3.5 million inhabitants of the province is 83 % Christian , but demographic trends are changing as Muslim economic migrants come from the populous islands of Java , Borneo , Sumatra and Sulawesi .
Javanese Warung-Kantinen sell fried chicken and Gado-Gado , a mixed vegetables served with peanut sauce .
Local people are fighting to keep up .

Migrants have begun selling chickens and vegetables on the traditional market cheaper than local Papua ,  says Abeth You , a 24-year-old Paniai resident who moved to the provincial capital of Jayapura .
'It has cost local Papua - the mama [ the women ] of Papua - their market ' .
Indonesian President Joko Widodo , popularly known as Jokowi , promised during his 2014 campaign to address inequalities and violations of rights in Papua .
The former carpenter secured 27 of the 29 districts of Papua , including Paniai , on the way to the presidential palace in Jakarta .
But little has changed in Papua , and today locals feel cheated .
Our hearts are broken because in 2014 we voted for Jokowi , with the expectation that he will meet our hopes that justice will be restored ,  says You .
Indeed , just two months after Jokowi ’ s inauguration in October , Paniai suffered a low point .
On December 7 , 2014 , a group of 11 children was out and sang Christmas songs in front of a campfire in Enarotali , when two Indonesian soldiers broke through darkness on a motorcycle .
The frightened children told them that they should turn on their spotlights .
One of the soldiers took offence at their clay and later came back with four soldiers , according to the local pastor Yavedt Tebai .
The soldiers who had drunk hunted and beat the group with their guns , said victims and witnesses .
Then one of the soldiers fired into the group of children .
A child , the 16-year-old Yulianus Yeimo , was hit so hard that he fell into the coma .
A few hours later , the building of the nearby government commission was set on fire and things escalated the next day .
About 1,000 young Papua men , women , and children gathered at a football pitch in front of the local police station and the military command center to demand justice .
They performed ceremonial hunting arches and performed the Waita dance of Papua ’ s Mee Pago-Stamm in a circle imitating a bird song .
Some demonstrators started throwing stones at police and military posts .

When the mood was heated , a command was sent to the soldiers via an internal radio : " If the masses resist more than three times , they shoot them dead , " says an official TIME document that was not released to the local media .
Yeremias Kayame , 56 , the leader of the Kego Koto quarter of Enarotali , saw the threat and called for rest and asked the crowd to return home .
